Note: Include a brief description of the example word bank used for the project, focusing on its relevance to the AI in Action project and how it contributes to better project management.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 8

Slide 8: Brainstorming Technique - Brain Netting

- Brain Netting overview:
  - Also known as "online brainstorming" or "virtual brainstorming."
  - A method of generating ideas through asynchronous collaboration within the team using digital platforms, such as online forums, chat applications, or collaborative document editors.
  - Allows for team members in different time zones or locations to contribute their ideas and feedback effectively.

- Application of Brain Netting in the AI in Action project:
  1. Utilize a shared online platform or document for team members to log their ideas, comments, and suggestions related to the project's challenges and objectives.
  2. Enable team members to review, add to, or refine others' inputs, fostering a collaborative and iterative approach to idea generation.
  3. Periodically discuss and evaluate the ideas proposed on the platform as a team, focusing on their feasibility and potential value to the project.

- Benefits of using Brain Netting for the project:
  1. Encourages participation and idea-sharing from all team members, regardless of their location or availability.
  2. Enhances team communication and collaboration in a flexible and accessible manner.
  3. Generates a greater variety of ideas and perspectives by giving each team member the opportunity to contribute and expand on others' inputs.

Example of a brain netting platform for the project:

[Image: A screenshot or mockup of the online platform or document used for brain netting in the AI in Action project. Show team members' input and collaboration.]

Note: Include a brief description of the example brain netting platform used for the project, focusing on its relevance to the AI in Action project and how it contributes to better project management.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 9

Slide 9: Brainstorming Technique - Reverse Brainstorming

- Reverse Brainstorming overview:
  - A problem-solving approach that involves exploring a problem or challenge by asking "What could cause this problem?" or "How could we achieve the opposite of the desired outcome?"
  - Helps to identify potential pitfalls or obstacles and generate innovative solutions by approaching the problem from a different perspective.

- Application of Reverse Brainstorming in the AI in Action project:
  1. Pose questions such as "What factors could cause the AI-based early-warning system to fail?" or "How could we ensure poor communication and collaboration in the project?"
  2. Have team members generate ideas or scenarios that may lead to these negative outcomes.

conversations.facetValue: help a master's degree student prepare a presentation on global project management using the AI in Action project case study and Hofstede's cultural dimensions.

allFacetValues.value: receive detailed information and guidance for creating a PowerPoint presentation on a global project, specifically focusing on cultural differences and brainstorming techniques, as per the given brief and using Hofstede's cultural dimensions and selected brainstorming methods.
English
help a master's degree student prepare a presentation on global project management using the AI in Action project case study and Hofstede's cultural dimensions.

conversation.content:
As a Masters degree student, YOu Have a project and the brief goes thus:


Component A is a team presentation of 25 minutes (with 5 minutes of questions).

As a group you will be required to create a PowerPoint presentation which will detail the planning and management issues of a global project.

1.Choose a project you know off or you are interested in provided it is global, whether completed or in progress, and make sure that you are able to gather the information that is necessary for your analysis;

2.There are two sets of slides in Blackboard > Learning Material > week 1. These slides give you directions how to use UWE resources to find a case project.

3.Use the tools as described below in section 3. Content below and participate in the workshops to practice each tool with your group.

The presentation will be live, and all group members will present ONE part of the Assignment for which they will be individually marked. Not all group members will get the same mark necessarily, it depends on the quality of their work and presentation in their own part. Group members who do not participate and contribute to the Assignment will have to re-sit as they will get 0. .

This assessment strategy is employed to produce the type of output required by professional project management practice that is developed by a typical project team; and to maximize learning opportunities with added values for students’ development and character building.

This assignment requires you to develop research skills and find information that is useful for the purpose of detecting organizational issues related to the global environment and construct a plan. You will have to work with University databases and search through a large volume of information from Professional associations.

If you have difficulty to choose a global project here are some choices:

SMART CITIES
EXAMPLES
https://www.apm.org.uk/blog/five-of-the-uk-s-most-exciting-smart-city-projects/
https://publications.iadb.org/en/international-case-studies-smart-cities-santander-spain

GLOBAL HEALTHCARE PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://www.bond.org.uk/news/2017/04/7-projects-improving-healthcare-around-the-world

GLOBAL MEDICAL AND BIOTECH RESEARCH PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://globalprojects.ucsf.edu/
https://www.nihr.ac.uk/explore-nihr/funding-programmes/global-health.htm
https://www.tendersinfo.com/healthcare-and-medical-pharma-projects.php
https://www.pharmaceuticalonline.com/doc/top-10-international-pharmaceutical-biotech-c-0001

GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://borgenproject.org/5-top-humanitarian-aid-organizations/
https://www.humanitarianprojectsinc.com/

These are some examples, you can find global projects in most industries.

Please do not just use Apple, Google or Toyota or any of these famous large organizations because you cannot have access to information about their projects. Choose projects about which you can discover information.

I strongly suggest that you attend the workshops and be proactive in forming groups in week 1 and use the Direction files in the Learning Materials folders showing you case study books to select project case studies.








2.Presentation Content & Structure
The live team presentations should not exceed 30 minutes including Q&A and feedback from the tutor. This means that the presentation should be approximately 25 minutes maximum. In a team of 5 people this means that each person will have to present their contribution for 5 minutes.

It is the responsibility of the team to allocate the parts of the work amongst them.


Content

Your task is to present your analysis & plan of a global project. You will choose the project as described in the section above.

STRUCTURE OF THE PRESENTATION - PARTS:

INTRODUCTION: introduce your project and your team and each team member’s contribution you are going to have a slide where you will attach next to each part the name of the team member who worked at it and who will present it.

ANALYSIS PART 1. Evaluate the challenges regarding such a project using the dimensions model from Binder
Evaluate the impact of environmental factors on this project.
oCollect information about the project environment through industry & professional reports and company literature or case studies. You do not need to do primary research and collect information from the organization people.

PLAN PART 2: Recommend the most appropriate method for managing your project using the Global Project Management Framework from Binder. This part will focus on:
1.a risk assessment based on the Global Project Management Framework
2.explain how you will deal with the issues of: international and intercultural communications, global team structures, and collaborative relationships with other organizations in the particular project
3.The team and project manager roles & skillset [competency maps/leadership framework/Belbin roles]

PLAN PART 3: Construct a Project Plan with objectives, a phase plan and collaboration tools and collaboration techniques as advised by Binder
*Note: be careful that the type of plan you present is linked to the methodology you chose. For example, if you select a specific agile methodology your plan should be based on the type of iterations of this method.

References: reports from industry or from organization/firm, company material and information from reputable sources (case studies, professional magazines articles etc.) and the sources from the models you use to conduct analysis






3.Preparation for Assignment A (mandatory)

Students are advised to attend the workshops because the Assignment consists of the use of a series of tools, each tool belonging to a part of the Assignment. Please look at the table below to see which workshops correspond to which tools and which parts of the Assignment.


Workshops Section in Assignment A Tool to use Workshop Session
Find a project
Introduction Use the slides Session 1
Detect the challenges Part 1 The Radar Chart Session 2
Detect success factors Part 1 The PIP Session 3
Describe the team competencies needed Part 2 Competency map Session 4
Design the project manager role & leadership Part 2 leadership framework Session 5
Describe the teams’ behavioural roles Part 2 Belbin team roles Session 6
Choose the way your teams will be creative Part 2 Brainstorming Techniques Session 7
Describe the cultural differences and challenges in your project Part 2 Hofstede cultural scores Session 8
Explain how you qill uaw technologies to deal with challenges Part 3 Collaboration platforms Session 9
Design project plan for your presentation Part 3 Already known tools Session 10

In preparing for this assessment, teams will be able to undertake a series of formative exercises and gain feedback in response. Expectations concerning the presentation will be discussed in workshops, and teams will also be able to present ONE draft presentation plan for formative review on the final workshop on week 10.



Your part of the project is to do the sessions 7 & 8; that is, Choose the way your teams will be creative (Brainstorming Techniques) and Describe the cultural differences and challenges in your project (Hofstede cultural scores)




The chosen global project is below, with all the information available.:

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS —
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to
HKD 325bn by 2031.
However, these projects are not without their problems.
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the
most significant initiatives in the world;
from the Olympics, the artificial island
of Lantau, to the International Space
Station.
One of the challenges currently
faced by project leaders and investors is
that projects do not perform well.
They underperform in terms
of execution, with significant cost and
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common.
Our research has shown this
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget,
over time, over and over again’.
This poor performance is not a
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly
consistent for over 70 years. It is also
common to different countries, sectors
and delivery in the private and public
sectors.
The scale of projects has been
increasing for decades. The largest
megaprojects have budgets that match
the gross domestic products of the largest countries.
The GDP of Hong Kong
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar
amount to the budget for China’s high
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This
large scale means that it is crucial for
the money spent on projects to be better
managed.
The impacts of funds of this
size being mismanaged can be felt on
a national and even international scale.
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects
under the Capital Works Programme
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects
required additional funding owing
to project specific circumstances, the
majority of approved projects were
delivered at or under the original
Approved Project Estimates (APE).
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the
projects and the amount represented
some 8% of the total provision of
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active
for the Industry, with approximately
850 Category A projects having their
final accounts settled. In terms of
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall
surplus of HKD 30bn.
Effectively, this means the
surplus generated at the portfolio
level was more than able to offset
the cost overruns incurred by a select
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong
is better than many other regions
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction
complexity as well as scale. They
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex
megaprojects in Hong Kong have
suffered from underperformance in
the form of delays, cost overruns
and/or quality failures in recent
years. These incidents have been
well documented through extensive
media coverage – leading to reduced
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project
are crucial and can set the tone and
influence its efficacy. One of the
challenges of project performance
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such
actions are undertaken, the harder
and more resource intensive it is to
rectify problems.
However, it is not always
easy to identify risky projects before
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared
to 2021. The Development Bureau
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery.
A key policy objective of the
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure
the effective planning, management
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and
works programmes in a safe, timely
and cost-effective manner and to
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack
the daily and deep involvement in
their projects. They need the right
monitoring tools and early-warning
-sign systems to help them in their
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these
projects, once completed, will form part of the database
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn.
The mean project value is HKD 550m.
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the
delayed projects.
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data,
two methods were selected: tracking
annual performance as a percentage
of the (1) outturn performance and
(2) the original plan.
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a
four-year project the first year would
have 25% progress, the second 50%
etc.
The data for the analysis
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the
forecasted outcomes will be used
in the future, so the dual reporting
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random
forrests, an artificial intelligence
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to
group the projects then extracted the
typical cashflows from the s-curves
and compared the fit of the curves.
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had
statistically significantly different
outcomes. The analysis resulted in
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the
lines of building or non-building
projects. Then the building projects
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD
150m or not and the non-building
projects were categorised by whether
the planned duration was less than
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy



L O O K I N G F O R W A R D
WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions
are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a
Class 1 cost estimate.




CASE STUDIES
SPOTTING RISK
ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.
THESE ARE TWO REAL-LIFE CASES WHERE THE AI SPOTTED RISKY
PROJECTS EARLY
We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD
1.3bn with a construction duration of 3.9 years. Project 1 has completed its first year of construction. Project 2
has completed its first two years of construction.
The latest cashflow information shows that project 1 has spent 1% of its cash and is nearly 29% complete when
measured against the originally planned duration. Project 2 is 51% complete and has spent 21% of its cash.
First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows
that this trend will reverse in the next
two years and exceed usual patterns
in years 4 and 5. The AI’s flag raises
questions about this unusual profile
of acceleration and suggests further
investigation.
Project 2 receives a yellow flag. The
project is spending its budget more
slowly than typical projects but it
forecasts that it will soon be in line
with others. The schedule flags show a similar pattern. Project 1 gets a red
flag for being very late if it can keep
up the expenditure as is (under the
assumption that this is not indicating
a big cost underrun).
Project 2 is progressing like a typical
project in Hong Kong and the AI assigned a green schedule flag. But the
AI raises questions about the plans
after year 5.
The AI also produces a cost forecast
of the final outturn cost. At the mo- ment Project 1 is forecasted to cost
HKD 4.0bn. For this estimate, the
AI assumes that the project will not
follow its own forecasted trajectory
but behave more like a typical project
in the future. However, the unusual
pattern of expenditure means that if
the project does indeed accelerate its
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true
the AI forecasts spending of HKD
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans
include adding more detailed project data, further developing
the AI to enhance the predictive power and extending the PSS to
railway projects in collaboration with other international regions. Our innovations will not only support Hong Kong’s ambitious vision but also benefit projects worldwide.


The Structure is below

Slide 1: Title Slide

Slide 2: Introduction
- Brief project overview
- Objective of the presentation
- Outline of presentation sections and team member responsibilities

Slide 3: Project Background
- Brief description of the chosen global project
- Problem statement / goal of the project
- Countries or locations involved

Slide 4: Brainstorming Techniques - Introduction
- Importance of creative brainstorming in global projects
- Brief overview of selected brainstorming techniques

Slides 5-9: Brainstorming Techniques – Details
- Explanation of each selected brainstorming technique (one technique per slide) with respect to the project. The techniques are Storyboarding, Mind Mapping, Word Banking, Brain Netting and Reverse Brainstorming.
- Include examples, benefits, and a brief explanation of how the technique will be applied in the project
- Discuss how to Use each brainstorming technique to choose a creative approach

Slide 10: Cultural Differences - Introduction
- Importance of understanding cultural differences in global projects
- Brief introduction to Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions

Slides 11-15: Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions - Country Comparisons
- A slide for each cultural dimension , comparing the two areas (Hongkong and United Kingdom) involved in the project. The cultural dimensions are Power distance, Individualism & Collectivism, Masculinity & Femininity, Uncertainty avoidance and Long-term Orientation. One cultural Dimension per slide.
- Include graphs or charts to illustrate differences and similarities
- Use Hofstede cultural scores to explain cultural differences and challenges

Slide 16: Cultural Challenges and Opportunities
- Summarize potential cultural challenges based on the cultural dimensions analysis
- Suggest strategies to address these challenges
- Highlight opportunities for cultural synergy and learning

Slide 17: Recommendations for Project Management
- Propose recommendations for improving the project’s intercultural communication and teamwork, based on your sessions 7 and 8 findings
- Reference your brainstorming technique choices and how they integrate into the overall project management strategy

Slide 18: Conclusion
- Recap the main takeaways from your analysis
- Reiterate the importance of understanding brainstorming techniques and cultural differences for successful global project management

Slide 19: References
- List sources and references used in the presentation


Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 10

Slide 10: Cultural Differences - Introduction

Title: Cultural Differences in the AI in Action Project: An Introduction

- Importance of understanding cultural differences in global projects
  - Text: In global projects like AI in Action, understanding and managing cultural differences is crucial to effective communication, teamwork, and overall project success.

- Brief introduction to Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions
  - Text: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions provide a framework for comparing and understanding cultural differences between countries. The dimensions include Power Distance, Individualism vs. Collectivism, Masculinity vs. Femininity, Uncertainty Avoidance, and Long-term Orientation.

- Relevance of Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions to the AI in Action project
  - Text: By examining Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions, we can identify potential challenges and opportunities in managing the Hong Kong Development Bureau's AI in Action project, which involves stakeholders from both Hong Kong and the United Kingdom.

Note: You may also consider adding a relevant image or graphic to this slide to make it more visually appealing while conveying the core message.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 11

Slide 11: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions - Power Distance

Title: Power Distance Comparison: Hong Kong & United Kingdom

- Definition of Power Distance
  - Text: Power Distance represents the extent to which people in a society accept and expect unequal distribution of power. A higher score indicates greater acceptance of hierarchy and authority, while a lower score implies a preference for equal power distribution and decision-making.

- Comparison of Power Distance scores between Hong Kong and the United Kingdom
  - Text: Hong Kong has a Power Distance score of 68, whereas the United Kingdom has a score of 35.
  - Include a bar graph comparing the Power Distance scores of Hong Kong and the United Kingdom.

- Implications for the AI in Action project
  - Text: This difference in Power Distance may impact decision-making processes, communication patterns, and hierarchy in the project.
    - Hong Kong team members may be more comfortable with a hierarchical structure and may not question authority as much.
    - UK team members may prefer a flatter structure and expect more equal input in decision-making.

- Strategies for managing Power Distance differences
  - Text: To address these differences, project managers should:
    - Establish clear communication channels, emphasizing open and respectful dialogue regardless of hierarchy.
    - Encourage active participation of all team members in decision-making to balance the influence of hierarchy.
    - Acknowledge the cultural expectations of both sides and create an environment that encourages the exchange of ideas and perspectives.

Note: You may also consider adding a relevant image or visual element to this slide to complement the content and provide a more engaging presentation.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 12

Slide 12: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions - Individualism vs. Collectivism

Title: Individualism and Collectivism Comparison: Hong Kong and United Kingdom

- Definition of Individualism vs. Collectivism:
  - Text: Individualism and Collectivism represent the degree to which people in a society prioritize individual goals and self-interest over group interests and cohesion. A higher score indicates a preference for individualism, whereas a lower score signifies a preference for collectivism.

- Comparison of Individualism vs. Collectivism scores between Hong Kong and the United Kingdom:
  - Text: Hong Kong has an Individualism score of 25, whereas the United Kingdom has a score of 89.
  - Include a bar graph comparing the Individualism and Collectivism scores of Hong Kong and the United Kingdom.

- Implications for the AI in Action project:
  - Text: This difference in Individualism and Collectivism may impact teamwork, collaboration, and decision-making in the project.
    - Hong Kong team members may prioritize group harmony and consensus, focusing on the collective good.
    - UK team members may place more emphasis on personal achievements and individual freedom, promoting a competitive environment.
 
- Strategies for managing Individualism and Collectivism differences:
  - Text: To address these differences, project managers should:
    - Foster a sense of shared purpose and team goals, emphasizing the importance of collaboration, open communication, and group successes.
    - Encourage individual contributions by acknowledging and valuing personal achievements within the context of the overall project.
    - Promote cultural awareness through team-building exercises and open discussions about cultural preferences and priorities.

Note: You may also consider adding a relevant image or visual element to this slide to maintain visual appeal and engagement throughout the presentation.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 13

Slide 13: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions - Masculinity vs. Femininity

Title: Masculinity and Femininity Comparison: Hong Kong and United Kingdom

- Definition of Masculinity vs. Femininity:
  - Text: Masculinity and Femininity represent the degree to which societies value assertiveness and achievement (masculine) or cooperation and caring (feminine). A higher score indicates a preference for masculine values, whereas a lower score signifies a preference for feminine values.

- Comparison of Masculinity vs. Femininity scores between Hong Kong and the United Kingdom:
  - Text: Hong Kong has a Masculinity score of 57, whereas the United Kingdom has a score of 66.
  - Include a bar graph comparing the Masculinity and Femininity scores of Hong Kong and the United Kingdom.

- Implications for the AI in Action project:
  - Text: The difference in Masculinity and Femininity scores may impact communication styles, work-life balance, and approach to conflict resolution in the project.
    - Hong Kong team members may have a slightly less competitive mindset, but still value achievement and assertiveness.
    - UK team members may place more emphasis on assertiveness, achievement, and success, with a focus on task-based accomplishments.

- Strategies for managing Masculinity and Femininity differences:
  - Text: To address these differences, project managers should:
    - Create a holistic working environment that respects both the need for achievement and the value of cooperation and collaboration.
    - Foster open communication and encourage a balance between assertiveness and empathy in discussions and decision-making processes.
    - Consider work-life balance objectives and the desire for personal growth and development when setting project goals and expectations.

Note: You may also consider adding a relevant image or visual element to this slide to enhance the aesthetic appeal and maintain audience engagement throughout the presentation.
Now, as detailed as possible, give me all the info needed for slide 14

Slide 14: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions - Uncertainty Avoidance

Title: Uncertainty Avoidance Comparison: Hong Kong and United Kingdom

- Definition of Uncertainty Avoidance:
  - Text: Uncertainty Avoidance represents the degree to which people in a society feel uncomfortable with ambiguity, risk, and uncertainty. A higher score indicates a strong preference for stability, rules, and clear guidelines, whereas a lower score signifies a more flexible, adaptable approach to change and uncertainty.

how can I link EQuIS and ArcGIS online to create a live dashboard?

To link EQuIS and ArcGIS Online to create a live dashboard, you can follow the steps below:

1. Create an EQuIS database and upload your data. Ensure that the EQuIS database contains data that is geocoded.

2. Login to your ArcGIS Online account and create a new dashboard.

3. Choose the layout and theme for your dashboard.

4. Add a map to the dashboard and ensure that the map is set to display the EQuIS data using the correct symbology.

5. Create web maps that display the EQuIS data in ArcGIS Online. Make sure to enable the live data feed for the web maps.

6. Create a web map that contains the data from the EQuIS database.

7. Configure the web map to display the EQuIS data using the correct symbology.

8. Use the "Add Widget" feature in ArcGIS Online to add a "Dashboard Indicator" widget to the dashboard.

9. Configure the dashboard indicator widget to show the live data feed from the EQuIS database.

10. Save and publish the dashboard.

By following these steps, you should be able to link EQuIS and ArcGIS Online to create a live dashboard that displays your geocoded data.

I have identified a opportunity in the industry. There is a industrial award supported by government departments that we can apply and be awarded together with our client, so that our work will be more recognized and help to develop client relationship, which hopefully will leads to more similar business projects,  Please help me draft a opening dialog to the management partner

Dear Management Partner,

I have identified an excellent opportunity for us to take advantage of in the industry. Currently, there is an industrial award that is supported by various government departments, and I believe that we have a great chance of being awarded if we apply. 

If we are successful in obtaining the award alongside our client, we will not only gain recognition for our hard work and commitment, but it will also help to strengthen our relationship with the client. This, in turn, could lead to more similar business projects and help us expand our customer base.

As a team, we have been working diligently towards offering industry-leading solutions and services to our clients. By applying for this award, we can showcase our dedication and commitment and solidify our position as a key player in the industry.

I would like to discuss this opportunity in more detail with you, and explore the possibility of us applying for the award. Thank you for your time, and I look forward to your response.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

conversations.facetValue: write a script discussing a project aimed at combating illegal mining in the Philippines for UN SDG 13.

allFacetValues.value: write a script with six people discussing a project to combat illegal mining in the Philippines for the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action.
English
write a script discussing a project aimed at combating illegal mining in the Philippines for UN SDG 13.

conversation.content:
Your task is to write a 500 word script with Alei, Anne, Krista, Emilia, Teya, and Trisha as speakers who will discuss their project. Their project is about helping solve illegal mining in the Philippines for United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 13. Please use the following outline as the basis of the script:

United Nations Sustainable Development Goal to Take: SDG 13 - Climate Action
Primary Issue - Illegal Mining 

MAIN ISSUE:
SAM
The Philippines is the fifth most mineral-rich country in the world. The country is rich in copper, nickel, gold and chromite. This in turn urges large and small mining companies to exploit our resources illegally. It has always been a controversial and alarming issue that the Philippines is prone to illegal mining. It does not only affect the different animal species that lose their natural habitat, but also us humans too. Illegal mining devastates the environment and pollutes the water, air, and soil through the release of toxic chemicals.

KRISTA
We chose illegal mining because it has a negative influence on the environment, economy, and people in our country. Our natural resources have depleted throughout time due to the use of unsustainable practices and products. Utilizing mercury and cyanide for fishing poisoned the country’s bodies of water and its surrounding land. The government also uses illegal mining for its own purposes, and as a result, legal mining workers have begun to lose their jobs. This has had a bad influence on the reputation of our country. Residents of the area have lost their houses, families, and, most importantly, their lives. It is unfair to be paid less than the minimum wage for a work that puts one's life in danger for someone’s interest.

SOLUTION:

ALEI
Our program is about Illegal mining. Given that many large corporations are harming our natural resources, we came up with an idea to inform people about this and urge them to take action to prevent large corporations from engaging in dangerous activities that will cause our natural resources to run out. We want to lobby a bill that will defend our natural resources from capitalists with the aid of Filipino citizens. File a lawsuit against corporations that, like mining, cause enormous harm to society and the environment. With these simple measures, we may regain our natural state and stop the destructive activities that our natural resources are subject to.

TRISHA
In mitigation of the rampant mining issue in the Philippines, our group wishes to take the Sustainable Approach towards resolving it. As for our advocacy in line with this, we plan to partner with organizations and/or groups that could aid us in implementing policies that could help us further our goal of upholding the Sustainable Development Goal No. 13 which is to limit and adapt to climate change by way of lessening the negative impacts and instances of mining. We wish to lobby House Bill No. 259 of the 19th Congress, introduced by [KABATAAN PARTY-LIST] Representative Raoul Danniel A. Manuel, [ACT TEACHERS PARTY-LIST] Representative France L. Castro, and [GABRIELA WOMEN'S PARTY] Representative Arlene D. Brosas, that has yet to be approved by the House of Representatives and go through the rest of the legislative process to become a fully realized law. Our advocacy to hopefully change that and implement a policy that will help mitigate the environmental disasters caused/worsened by mining operations in the country.

Republic Act 7942 of 1995 is the law this house bill wishes to amend or reorient (as the bill calls it). Though it liberalized the domestic mining industry of the Philippines, it allowed for much environmental degradation to occur on top of harming the homes and lands of local indigenous communities as it allowed foreign access to the country's natural resources. The benefits this RA hoped to achieve was criticized for not being enough to weigh out the consequences it inflicted. This new bill we seek to lobby has the goal of implementing a sustainable approach to the Philippine mining industry, and finding balance between agriculture and industrialization.
For more information/reading on how the proposed bill details its intentions, refer here:

IMPACT OF PROJECT:
LIA
Enable the Philippines to leap towards a cleaner, more resilient economy by implementing policies essential for the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal 13 that will encourage individuals to collaborate and join the program, as well as quicken the pace of change to become a roadmap for climate actions that will reduce emissions and build climate resilience.

ANNE
Furthermore, our program aims to collaborate with well-known and influential NGOs, Television and Radio Stations in the Philippines to implement policies our program will produce with regard to the illegal mining activities in the country. This project is one of the essential avenues to make room for new and improved policies to help our environment recover from the damages we inflicted. Our project also intends to become a space where young adults like ourselves can participate. Lastly, we envision a future where young adults like us can voice our ideas, influence the masses, involve others for a better cause, and improve our surroundings for us and future generations.

Title: Advocating for Sustainability: Combating Illegal Mining in the Philippines

(Introductory Statements)

ALEI:
Hello, we are a group of dedicated individuals committed to making a change in our society. Today, we want to discuss an alarming issue that affects the environment, economy, and people in the Philippines. Our project focuses on combating illegal mining in support of the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action.

ANNE:
Illegal mining has exposed the vulnerability of our environment and people to toxic chemicals, leading to poverty, deforestation, polluted water, and air. In our pursuit to create a cleaner and more resilient economy, we have come up with a plan to mitigate the effects of illegal mining and promote sustainable development.

MAIN ISSUE:

EMILIA:
The Philippines is the fifth most mineral-rich country globally, abundant in copper, nickel, gold, and chromite. This wealth has sparked a controversial and alarming issue of illegal mining. It endangers various animal species, their natural habitat, and human lives. Illegal mining devastates the environment and pollutes the water, air, and soil through toxic chemical releases.

TEYA:
We chose illegal mining as our focus because of its detrimental impacts. Our natural resources have depleted over time due to unsustainable practices and products. Mercury and cyanide used for fishing have poisoned the country's water bodies and surrounding land. Furthermore, the government manipulates illegal mining for personal gain, causing loss of jobs for legal miners and damage to our country's reputation. This has led to the displacement of families, loss of lives, and workers being underpaid for their laborious and dangerous work.

SOLUTION:

KRISTA:
Our program aims to raise awareness about illegal mining and advocate for stronger legislation to protect our natural resources from exploitation. We want Filipinos to join our cause and lobby a bill against corporations causing harm to society and the environment. We believe that through collective action and lawful enforcement, we can preserve our natural resources and put an end to these destructive activities.

TRISHA:
To combat illegal mining, we propose a sustainable approach. We plan to partner with organizations and groups to implement policies in line with SDG 13. Our goal is to lobby House Bill 259, which aims to shift the Philippine mining industry towards sustainability and balance between agriculture and industrialization. By amending the existing Republic Act 7942 of 1995, we hope to mitigate the negative impacts caused by mining and reduce harm to indigenous communities.

IMPACT OF PROJECT:

LIA:
This project will enable the Philippines to move towards a cleaner, more resilient economy by implementing essential policies for SDG 13. We want to encourage individuals to participate in our program, accelerating climate action that leads to reduced emissions and increased climate resilience.

ANNE:
Finally, our program seeks collaboration with influential NGOs, TV & Radio stations to help implement policies addressing illegal mining in the Philippines. Our project provides an avenue for young adults, like us, to voice our ideas, influence the masses, involve others for a better cause, and improve our surroundings for current and future generations.

(Conclusion)

ALL:
Together, we can make a difference. It is our responsibility to stand up for the environment, the economy, and our fellow Filipinos' well-being. We believe in a sustainable future, and through our combined efforts, we can help tackle illegal mining and work towards a brighter future for everyone. Thank you for your support.

conversations.facetValue: help a student understand how to prepare a project presentation on global project management.

allFacetValues.value: get guidance on completing a group project presentation on the planning and management of a global project, including selecting a project, preparing the presentation, and understanding the required content and structure.
English
help a student understand how to prepare a project presentation on global project management.

conversation.content:
Explain to me in details how to get the following project done


Presentation Brief Component A 
Main Information 
Component A is a team presentation of 25 minutes (with 5 minutes of questions). 

As a group you will be required to create a PowerPoint presentation which will detail the planning and management issues of a global project. 

1.Choose a project you know off or you are interested in provided it is global, whether completed or in progress, and make sure that you are able to gather the information that is necessary for your analysis; 	 

2.There are two sets of slides in Blackboard > Learning Material > week 1. These slides give you directions how to use UWE resources to find a case project. 

3.Use the tools as described below in section 3. Content below and participate in the workshops to practice each tool with your group. 

The presentations will take place online on the 27/04/2023 using Blackboard Collaborate. Times and schedule of group presentations to be posted on Blackboard during the second week of the module. 

The presentation will be live, and all group members will present ONE part of the Assignment for which they will be individually marked. Not all group members will get the same mark necessarily, it depends on the quality of their work and presentation in their own part. Group members who do not participate and contribute to the Assignment will have to re-sit as they will get 0. . 

Information about groups will be in section 4. Groups below. 

This assessment strategy is employed to produce the type of output required by professional project management practice that is developed by a typical project team; and to maximize learning opportunities with added values for students’ development and character building.

This presentation accounts for 75% of the final grade.










Contents
aCADEMIC YEAR 2022/23	1
Presentation Brief Component A	1
1.	Selecting a project	3
2.	Presentation Content & Structure	4
3.	Preparation for Assignment A (mandatory)	5
4.	Groups	6
Appendix: Marking grid	8









1.Selecting a project 

This assignment requires you to develop research skills and find information that is useful for the purpose of detecting organizational issues related to the global environment and construct a plan. You will have to work with University databases and search through a large volume of information from Professional associations. 

If you have difficulty to choose a global project here are some choices: 

SMART CITIES
EXAMPLES 
https://www.apm.org.uk/blog/five-of-the-uk-s-most-exciting-smart-city-projects/ 
https://publications.iadb.org/en/international-case-studies-smart-cities-santander-spain 

GLOBAL HEALTHCARE PROJECTS 
EXAMPLES 
https://www.bond.org.uk/news/2017/04/7-projects-improving-healthcare-around-the-world 

GLOBAL MEDICAL AND BIOTECH RESEARCH PROJECTS 
EXAMPLES 
https://globalprojects.ucsf.edu/ 
https://www.nihr.ac.uk/explore-nihr/funding-programmes/global-health.htm
https://www.tendersinfo.com/healthcare-and-medical-pharma-projects.php 
https://www.pharmaceuticalonline.com/doc/top-10-international-pharmaceutical-biotech-c-0001 

GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN PROJECTS 
EXAMPLES
https://borgenproject.org/5-top-humanitarian-aid-organizations/ 
https://www.humanitarianprojectsinc.com/

These are some examples, you can find global projects in most industries. 

Please do not just use Apple, Google or Toyota or any of these famous large organizations because you cannot have access to information about their projects. Choose projects about which you can discover information. 

I strongly suggest that you attend the workshops and be proactive in forming groups in week 1 and use the Direction files in the Learning Materials folders showing you case study books to select project case studies. 








2.Presentation Content & Structure 
The live team presentations should not exceed 30 minutes including Q&A and feedback from the tutor. This means that the presentation should be approximately 25 minutes maximum.  In a team of 5 people this means that each person will have to present their contribution for 5 minutes. 

It is the responsibility of the team to allocate the parts of the work amongst them. 


Content 

Your task is to present your analysis & plan of a global project. You will choose the project as described in the section above. 

STRUCTURE OF THE PRESENTATION - PARTS: 

INTRODUCTION: introduce your project and your team and each team member’s contribution you are going to have a slide where you will attach next to each part the name of the team member who worked at it and who will present it.

ANALYSIS PART 1. Evaluate the challenges regarding such a project using the dimensions model from Binder   
Evaluate the impact of environmental factors on this project.
oCollect information about the project environment through industry & professional reports and company literature or case studies. You do not need to do primary research and collect information from the organization people.
